content:
Located in the southern Peloponnesian peninsula, Pavlopetri (the modern name of the site) <question_0> a Neolithic settlement around 3500 B.C. and became an important trading center for Mycenaean Greece (1650-1180 B.C.). This area of the Aegean Sea is <question_1> earthquakes and tsunamis, which caused the city to <question_2> sink. The slow sea level rise in Mediterranean submerged this city around 3000 years ago.

For millennia, the city's remains lay unseen below some 13 feet of water. They were <question_3> a thick layer of sand off the island of Laconia. In recent decades, shifting currents and climate change have <question_4> a natural barrier that protected Pavlopetri. In 1967 a scientific survey of the Peloponnesian coast was gathering data to analyze changes in sea levels <question_5> British oceanographer Nicholas Flemming first spotted the sunken structures. A year later, he returned with a few students to <question_6> the location and map the site. <question_7> the exciting initial finds, the site would lie <question_8> for decades before archaeologists would return.

In 2009 archaeologists Chrysanthi Gallou and Jon Henderson <question_9> the excavation of Pavlopetri <question_10> the Greek Ministry of Culture. Since the 1960s, underwater archaeology techniques and tools <question_11> huge advances. The team <question_12> robotics, sonar mapping, and <question_13> graphics to survey the site. From 2009 to 2013 they were able to <question_14> the underwater town. Covering about two and a half acres, Pavlopetri's three main roads <question_15> some 50 <question_16> buildings, all of which had open courtyards. Excavations revealed a large number of Minoan-style loom weights, <question_17> Pavlopetri was a <question_18> trade center with a <question_19> textile industry.
